comments.commentBody:
In this difficult world, everyone knows about Russia's misdeeds, particularly its lust for grabbing power wherever it can. The respect to rule of law and societal values in the American society are definitely absent in Russia. The present news scandal gets the color of truth, as there is a continuous refusal to blame Russia for interfering with US Democracy. This point has to be seriously noted.
There seems to be a war of words between present and future 'tenses' - as between tackling the email hacking issue (the present tense) is confused with the US-Russia relations (the future tense). So, first thing first. We have to first solve the issue of unfair Russian Aggression or rather intervention in US Democracy, i.e. tackling the issue at hand.

Cookies are yummy. We are enjoying them with morning cup of tea. so I have not made them as sandwich but just cookies. I halved the amount of sugar, reduced amount of dates, cinnamon and replaced flour with whole wheat flour.

On my second attempt, I made some alterations based on suggestions here:
I needed bacon for another purpose, so I cooked it in my dutch oven then cooked the cabbage in the grease at 350 for 40 min until browned (my oven runs hot).
In another pan, I combined butter, anchovies, garlic, thyme, red pepper, then added lemon juice and a splash of white wine, then panko bread crumbs. This softened the bread crumbs, but I found the original a tad dry.
I combined it all and used fettuccine as my pasta.
Excellent just as it is! I added a little sugar to the cucumber pickle but that was it!

Tried just using garam masala. Not wild about it. The cloves really overpowered the salmon and the cucumber. If there's a next time, I'll either try the curry powder substitute or follow the recipe and make my own.

This is a warming soup, lovely in its simplicity. Not sure why the recipe calls for simmering for 50 minutes; even with "roughly" chopped carrots and parsnip, 20 minutes is more than enough for the vegetables to get super tender. Add spices and herbs for more complexity of flavor.
see step 1

Very interesting article. I wish Mr. Obama had discussed this more often.

Automation and its opportunities and negatives have been around a long time. I got into this topic in the 80s during the Reagan double-dip recessions. It was a pretty rough time for the economy and those who were in policy jobs were searching for pathway solutions. I met with Wassily Leontief, whose name came to my attention through his article in Scientific American on the distribution of incomes and jobs. It was a well researched article and bottom line he suggested that as automation soaked up traditional jobs, it would be a good idea to cut the work week and free workers for more leisure activities & to pursue personal entrepreneurial activities. He showed me in his input-output tables that this change, if managed properly, would improve the distribution of incomes & jobs & create more pleasure.

2nd thought: Electricity is fundamental to automation and eventually because of population growth, finite limits to fossil fuels including the challenges of global warming that eventually we will need to build a system of space solar satellites to beam power to Earth grids. My colleague, Dr, James Powell, has authored a book, "Silent Earth", that describes this space solar satellite system that will deliver very cheap electric power to all of the Earth's people to power our needs for a modern standard of living. The energy efficiency should unleash the economic forces that will increase prosperity.
Read Thomas Friedman's, "Thank You for Being Late".  It sounds like Obama has.

Jon,
I have it on my list. I am happy that President Obama was giving this issue emphasis. It just did not get picked up by the media.

O Frabjous Friday. Really enjoyed this one.

Regarding 1D, not sure if it's true, but I've heard that they don't have any blood banks in north western England. Which would be curious, since there is a Liverpool. (rim shot)

good challenging puzzle. knew Beth March, Rickey Henderson (Yanks fan), Efrem Zimbalist which helped me get started. Did not know George Dickey but crossings helped with rye whisky. Long answers Museum Exhibit and Buyers Remorse and Parody Account I got with help from crosses.
But Ricky was an Oakland A when he broke the record.  Every one at the game got a special pin, I still wear mine on my game-day cap.

George Dickel, please.

I was impressed with the accuracy of the clue. Dickel is one of the very few American distilleries to label their products "whisky," in the Scottish style, and not "whiskey," in the Irish tradition. And they do, in fact, market a "Rye Whisky," possibly the only American product so labeled.

Canadian whisky uses that spelling, and is mostly rye, but it is normally labeled just "whisky" or "Canadian whisky." Canadian bottles carrying the designation "Rye whisky" are rare, although almost all whisky made in Canada could be described as such.

But for a clue for RYE WHISKY, "George Dickel product" is unimpeachable.

Causes and conditions and the US's out-dated Electoral College system which gave voters in "the Rust Belt" an advantage, gave Trump the win in this election. So be it.  If perceptions of true success and power are based on how much money one controls, we all lose. Economic nostalgia is a double-edged sword. The world moves on. It's a cliche, but he with the most toys/money when he dies, does not win.

First as indicated by the recent results the Electoral college is doing those things that it was intended to do and is therefore not outdated at all.  Now I agree with your view of toys/money.  Recently I was reminded that my current investment and spending strategy would result in money being left after my death, my response is to create a charitable trust to do good after my death.  The amount of good is the correct measure or the effect on the world.  So say Tesla is much more remembered than others with just a lot of money.
It sure is, at the expense of more than half of the citizens.

Then the game is a fundamentally foolish one -- and "rigged" as well. Institute near-100-percent estate taxes, and universal free early and higher education and health care, and at least everyone's capitalist-economy "scorecard" would start equal; but IMO those who devote their lives to trying to win that game are in fact bankrupt.

My 2nd attempt at a reply.
No, St. Peter was the !st Pope (33 AD) and he probably rode on a donkey as the use of chariots in Rome during the day was restricted, same Rome, same traffic problems.

In my 1st reply I used the A-word for donkey, and in the past I have found that the use of that word gets a comment disapproved.
Cubans come through Florida, not our Southwest border.
Dear Deb, in my discussion with Barry about Popemobiles I used the A-word for donkey i.e. the animal Jesus rode on (as does the bible).  Why are comments with the A-word rejected?

Hi Bruvver,

I answered your question below. I'm still in negotiations with the mods because the word gets caught in the profanity filter. I've told them that the word is sometimes used in the puzzle and that we should be able to use it in the comments, but they're not convinced.

They are currently unable to lift the filter for some place and not others, and they don't want to eliminate it for everyone, which is understandable.
Don't some get away with it by u$ing other $ymbols?
Not for long. :)

I sure exceptions will be made for those likely (or certain) to be persecuted on their return. In the 1980's, I hosted Cuban dissident Reinaldo Arenas in my Lawrence apartment for 45 minutes, just the two of us chatting one-on-one about being gay here in the US versus there on the island. What he told me was riveting and depressing, even as it was clear he was thrilled to be in a country that was well on the way to ending all legal prosecution and social stigmatism of gays and lesbians. We must continue to alllow people, regardless of their feet's wetness/dryness, to stay if they are likely to be presecuted on their return.
There are already protections covering all people arriving here who face real risk of persecution if they return home.

Much has changed since the 80's and the type of persecution Arenas faced in Cuba then is unheard of now.  Gay marriage is legal.  Raul Castro's daughter has forced legislation in Cuba to grant equal rights to all Cubans regardless of gender, sexual preference or gender identification.  Yes, there are hate crimes, as there are here.. but as you say, people in real danger in their own countries, regardless if it is Cuba, El Salvador or Mexico (and the list continues) ought to seek and be granted political asylum here.   Sadly, Cubans have indeed taken advantage of this preferential treatment the US provided them for decades, and freely traveled back and forth.  That majority of Cubans were not at all political refugees, and in doing so, denigrated the true hardship people like Arenas and others faced.
But it's Ok for Mexicans?
Trump does not hate immigrants.  He is married to one.  He just believes we should enforce our laws.  Illegal immigrants are overwhelming our social services!
Bravo.  I couldn't agree more.
Haiti and Honduras are more dangerous and oppressive than Cuba.

Wow.....
To appease a dictator, Obama is willing to close the doors to refugees from an oppressive regime.

You could make that same exact argument for so many other countries. Cubans are not excluded from seeking asylum, but their plight is no worse than many others and should not receive preferential treatment.

Where did you get that from? An overly favorable policy first set up to spite said oppressive regime is finally terminated because its recipients are no longer refugees, but economic migrants; that's it. Obama can't be suspected of being perfect, but in this case, he made the right move, for the right reasons (at least, the official ones).
Wait! Am I being punked, here? Am I having a seizure? Where in the world is TENK a word?
MOL, that was the little section I never completed, and I have plenty of TEN Ks over the years, and yet that never occurred to me.
Oh, lord, I knew I'd be embarrassed--I actually got it not long ago under a different definition--a race, I think.
I knew I was gonna be embarrassed. It was in the Times not very long ago, as a race or a workout, or something. I got it that time. (Either I solved it or I recognized it when it showed up.)

The emus have gotten smarter. In the early days of the Crossword Forum (roughly in the dial-up era), a post was rejected because of a typo that omitted the second "n" in "peninsula."

Those proto-emus were either even dumber or, alternatively, had an impressive knowledge of Latin word formation.
Oh please, if they don't like it they can change it anytime.

Agree, Terrier and DR...which is why I expected Trump to name Carson to be the next Surgeon General. I doubt I was the only one. It makes sense and would put Carson in the field he is a qualified expert in.
Instead, Trump names Carson to be Secretary of HUD because he grew up in a poor black urban neighborhood decades ago. (I assume, it's the only logical explanation.)
Doesn't seem to be a case of putting the best person in the best position.
Obviously they just haven't been quoted on TV yet.  Trump doesn't really read things, so he hasn't noticed any of this so far.
